msIdentifier.repository: Historical Society of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA

msItem.title: Journal entry
Journal C of Station No. 2 of the Underground Railroad, Agent William Still, 1852-1857

history.acquisition: Held in trust by HSP on behalf of the Pennsylvania Abolition Society

projectDesc.p: The William Still Digital History Project weaves new connections between the manuscript journal and published book of William Still, known as the "Father of the Underground Railroad." Through text encoding, mapping, and other interpretive and contextual resources, this project will provide insight into the experiences of enslaved individuals and families who passed through Philadelphia between 1852 and 1857 and the covert networks that aided their escape.

editorialDecl.p: This electronic file was created using manual keying following the recommendations for Level 4 of "Best Practices for TEI in Libraries" guidelines v3.0.

We have generally encoded entire documents/texts, not excerpts. We have encoded page breaks. We have also preserved original spelling, typographical errors, missing text, and original capitalization. We have regularized spacing between words and sentences to replace double (or triple) spaces to a single space.
We have not coded line breaks, end-of-line hyphenation, visual rendition of layout, font changes, or text alignment (left, right, center).
Annotation on people and organizations coded in this document can be found in Still_project_people.xml and Still_project_organizations.xml.
See project web site at http://hsp.org/underground-railroad for full description of the editorial practices in the William Still Digital History Project.
This XML file uses unique entity identifiers, media file identifiers, and collection identifiers in HSP's Digital Library, available at http://digitallibrary.hsp.org

revisionDesc.change: Added more corrections for canonical TEI plans.
Journal C excerpts copied into separate files.

div.p:
Arrived_ NAME of America Co. Md. arrived with her 5 children, as follows: NAME, NAME, NAME, NAME & NAME
Because of her audacity in fleeing with so many children in their master's carriage, Harriet and her children and companions were closely pursued. She was assisted by NAME, a Quaker conductor in Wilmington, Delaware. He forwarded them safely to underground stations in southeastern Pennsylvania, from which they ultimately arrived in Philadelphia. Once there, the NAME wasted no time in placing them on safe trains for Canada.; all hail looking. Her husband, who lived near Chestertown, was left behind.
Harriet left because she did not receive kind treatment from her Mistress, besides her Master's Farther was a "Georgia Trader", and she was fearful of falling into his hands.

To facilitate their flight the mother
with her cildren, with 5 others helped themselves to their masters horses & carriges (two carriages) and so came â€“ rode into Wilmington, and from thence, after leaving the carriages, were sent on a by way. Theyir oppertunities for improvement had not been favourable, evidently_ as was the clearly evidenced by their manners and ways indicated.
